awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: IUSE-EHR: Cultivating Inclusive Identities of Engineers and Computer Scientists: Expanding Efforts to Infuse Inclusive Excellence in Undergraduate Curricula
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to develop inclusive professional identities among engineering and computer science students through the process of redesigning undergraduate curricula. Inclusive professional identities are defined here as engineering and computer science students with: (a) the necessary technical knowledge, skills, and abilities to work in their chosen field, (b) an appreciation for how all kinds of diversity strengthen engineering and computer science as disciplines, and (c) knowledge of how to act in inclusive ways and create inclusive environments within their field. This project builds on a prior exploratory IUSE grant to develop, implement, and assess curricula for first-year engineering courses designed to help beginning engineering students identify with an inclusive vision of the engineering profession. The first objective is to transfer the first-year curricula to three other universities with different institutional characteristics and extend this curricula from engineering into computer science. Throughout this process, the pathways and barriers to successful transfer and adoption of this curricula will be studied. The second objective is to expand efforts into the second and third year courses in engineering and computer science in ways that sustain student engagement with diversity and inclusion. The project will develop and assess (a) discipline- and course-specific diversity activities (in particular, case studies from the engineering and computer science profession), and (b) training for graduate teaching assistants and faculty to facilitate effective and inclusive teams. The third objective is to measure both the short term and long term impact of the diversity and inclusion activities on the development of inclusive professional identities in students. 

The intellectual merit of this project lies in its transformative approach toward changing engineering and computer science collegiate cultures. This work complements initiatives that support historically underrepresented populations: rather than focusing exclusively on members of underrepresented groups, the focus is on preparing all students to work in diverse environments and to leverage inclusive behaviors that will support retention of students in STEM from all backgrounds, underrepresented and majority alike. The broader impact of this project allows for development and distribution of curricula that will prepare all STEM students to enact inclusive professional behaviors. Creating inclusive climates in collegiate STEM departments contributes to broadening participation by ensuring that students from underrepresented groups experience equitable learning environments where they can participate fully in STEM learning. STEM professionals who are prepared to infuse diverse perspectives in their everyday practices and create inclusive work environments carry great potential to make robust contributions for the public good of society.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, engineering and computer science educators and education researchers at four institutions: Colorado State University, West Virginia University, University of Denver, and Metropolitan State University of Denver, worked together to develop curriculum and activities to support the development of inclusive professional identities in engineering and computer science students. As a research team, we defined inclusive professional identities in terms of four key components: 1) competence in applying disciplinary knowledge, skills, and abilities, 2) appreciation of how diversity strengthens a discipline, 3) an ability to act in inclusive ways and create inclusive environments, and 4) consideration of a professional endeavor’s impact on diverse populations.  This project built on a smaller pilot project centered on first-year engineering students at Colorado State University and sought to transfer first-year activities from CSU to the other institutions, develop and assess new activities for sophomore and junior level courses, and consider a broader range of engineering disciplines and computer science.

First-year activities included welcome presentations from college leadership to set an inclusive college norm, interactive theater performances about working in groups and addressing bias or conflict in groups, and reflection activities related to the impact of biases on engineering design. Some of these activities have been institutionalized at CSU and will continue beyond the end of the grant.

Examples of new course curriculum include an activity about diverse perspectives in problem solving for an engineering mechanics class, activities about societal context and serving diverse individuals in materials, thermodynamics, hydrology, and nonpoint source pollution, and reflection prompts about group work in chemical and biological engineering courses. Publications analyzing student responses to these activities and presentations and workshops about the use of such activities help inspire other engineering and STEM instructors with activities they could use in class and help these instructors anticipate student responses so they can be prepared to promote student learning during class discussions. A key finding from this research was that the data used to teach students how to perform calculations can be a powerful teaching tool regarding the social context of engineering. In the hydrology class students performed calculations that revealed the structural racism embedded in the infrastructure of different neighborhoods that influenced the amount of runoff that occurs during rain storms, and in the non-point source pollution class students engaged directly with data related to race, class, and clean drinking water access. In both classes these topics were integrated into existing content, rather than replacing content, and students were particularly receptive to the content, when compared to students in some of the other courses and interventions we studied. Thus, having students engage directly with data in this way has the potential to be a gateway for deeper conversations around societal context and engineering, and provides a pathway for curricular change that does not require new topics to be added to already full courses. 

As the project proceeded, the research team recognized the importance of understanding student’s existing experiences with diversity and faculty attitudes about teaching societal context in engineering courses. We conducted 73 interviews with students in senior design about their experiences in class-based groupwork, internships, and on campus diversity organizations.  We found that some students are experiencing work on diverse teams during their degree program, but this experience is inconsistent. Internship experiences with diversity also varied widely. Nearly a third of interviewees reported experiencing some form of bias during their internships. Diversity and identity affinity spaces were valuable to many students, but there was some concern about the potential for division and a desire for spaces where the societal context of engineering was relevant but not necessarily identity focused. A small survey of faculty at CSU and DU found that while many faculty appreciate the idea of teaching engineering and computer science students about diversity, equity and inclusion, far fewer faculty believe this is the responsibility of engineering or computer science educators or are comfortable teaching such lessons themselves.

This project contributed to a growing body of literature about how engineering and computer science educators can incorporate lessons about diversity, equity, and inclusion in technical courses and provided insight about existing student and faculty attitudes toward such content.
